comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content:
I remember being taken up the Pillar by my grandmother Christmas '65. There were turnstiles inside the porch where the pillar man collected sixpences and monitored how many were up at any one time. There were two stiles one for ups and the other for downs. The difference between the counters being the numbers up. While there was 168 steps the climb seemed to go on for ever. People going up were supposed to stay to the inside because of the tapered steps-- It being safer to climb on a toe than descend on a heel.--- The only natural light came in through the odd loop hole. It was poorly electrically lit otherwise. The only sounds were those of other visitors with no sounds of the street outside. I remember being quite frightened looking down. The statue itself was very weather beaten and lacked sharp detail and Nelsons head itself was very worn--or had not been carved to great detail in the first place?
I went to national school in Dalkey and it was the conductor on the No8 bus who told me that the Pillar had been blown up the night before. My Da brought us in to see the stump the following evening after our swim in Tara Street baths.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Christmas '95? It went bang in 1966?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The tram driver has a metal rod which he/she pokes into the point box. It can take some levering to move the points. Even the new Blackpool trams carry point levers. There is a metal ball hanging at head height to operate the overhead switch. The conductor pulls this down as the driver drives through the points. When the trolley head passes through the overhead switch, the conductor raps the ball twice on the metal post to let the driver know. Trolley buses also used this method at junctions. www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach/1469303824/in/set-72... Way back in 1974 Melbourne Victoria had automatic points on the St Kilda route. The driver opened the controller which moved the track points and overhead switch. This was when trams still had trolley poles instead of modern pantographs. Here is my video of Blackpool points on YouTube

comment.author: 91549360@N03

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Another ritual was swinging the trolley boom at the end of the route. Heritage trams still carry a long bamboo pole with a hook on the end. Some trams had a rope hanging for the conductor to pull the boom down. That's when the tram lights went out. It was a long walk around the tram with the pole/rope and then some skill to pop the trolley head back onto the overhead wire. I did this a few times at Beamish Museum. I never missed the wire!! Here is YouTube video of a conductor not knowing that the boom only goes around one way.

comment.author: 8420103@N05
comment._content: That's a fabulous photo. I hadn't realised until today how much of the pillar was actually blown up in the first explosion. If you look at the morning after detail below, you will see that everything from a little above the first lighthole went, and the little circle on which the statue stood was caught on its way down by the stump and remained precariously balanced there until the subsequent army explosion which demolished the rest of the circular pillar. . Look at the main photo again and see how much was blown away. The explosive must have had enormous compression inside the pillar structure. The detail above is from this wider shot below: I wonder if there is a forensic/explosives analysis of it anywhere. If not, there might be a stray PhD wandering around waiting to be picked up. :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
